text:
IDIOMATIC EXPRESSION

Idioms are groups of two or more words which must be learnt as a whole because the meaning of the expression may be different from the meaning of its parts.

List of idiomatic expressions and their meaning (A – B)

  1.       a bad egg - a worthless person
  2.       above one’s head - too difficult to understand
  3.       a cat’s paw - one used as a tool to do something dangerous
  4.       a chip of the old block - very much like the father
  5.       a close shave - a narrow escape
  6.       a cock – and - bull Story - an absurd and unbelievable story
  7.       a feather in one’s cap - an honour or distinction
  8.       a flash in the pan - a one and only success
  9.       a good Samaritan - one who is kind and compassionate to someone in distress
  10.   a hard nut to crack - a difficult problem
  11.   apple pie order - in perfect order
  12.   a pretty kettle of fish - a state of confusion
  13.   a Skeleton in the cupboard - a dreadful family secret
  14.   a snake in the grass – an enemy who strikes under cove
  15.   a Spartan life - a life of extreme self-discipline to maintain the health of body and mind
  16.   a storm in a teacup - much excitement about something small
  17.   a wet blanket - a discouraging person
  18.   a white elephant - something useless and expensive to keep an eye for an eye retaliation, revenge
  19.   a nine days’ wonder - an event which creates a sensation for a time but is soon forgotten
  20.   an open secret – common knowledge, what everyone knows
  21.   armed to the teeth - completely armed
  22.   arm’s length – avoiding intimacy or close contact
  23.   as likely as not - probably
  24.   as the crow flies - in a straight line at
  25.   a loose end - having nothing interesting to do
  26.   at loggerheads with - quarrelling
  27.   at the eleventh hour -at the last moment
  28.   beat about the bush - approach a matter in an indirect manner
  29.   behind the scenes - in private
  30.   bite more than one can chew – taking more responsibility than you can carry out.
  31.   bite one’s head off - answer sharply or angrily
  32.   bite the dust - to fail, die or stop existing
  33.   blow one’s trumpet - boast
  34.   break the ice be - the first to begin
  35.   bring down the house - cause rapturous applause
  36.   bring one to one’s senses - cause one to stop foolish or wild behavior
  37.   build castles in the air - day-dream
  38.   burn the candle at both ends - work too hard
  39.   bury the hatchet - make peace
  40.   butter someone up - flatter
  41.   by any means - in any way possible
  42.   by hook or by crook - by fair or foul means at whatever cost or risk
  43.   by leaps and bounds - with remarkable speed or progress

 

 

UNN PUTME Example

"An open secret" means

A. an open matter. B. a fact that is very secret. C. a secret known to everybody. D. a confidential matter

(a secret known to everybody).

 

Example

When asked to state her side of the story, Bunmi started by beating about the bush. This means that Bunmi

A. went straight to the point. B. was lost in great thought. C. followed a bush path. D. approached the subject without coming to the point.

(approached the subject without coming to the point).

 

Example

I knew Okoronkwo's father very well and I must say that his son is a chip off the old block. Thy means that Okoronkwo

A. has Chosen the game career as its father. B. is very much like his father. C. is a I extremely different sort of person from his lather. D. has taken up a different profession from his father's.

(is very much like his father)

 

Example

In their desire to impress their friends and relatives, many young workers bite off more than they can chew in terms of financial obligations.

A. have more money than sense B. eat more than they can digest property C. spend too much money on food D. care too much for their relatives E. take on more responsibility than they can afford.

(take on more responsibility than they can afford)

 

List of idiomatic expressions and their meaning (C – F)

  1.   can’t make head or tail of - can’t understand at all
  2.   carried away - very excited
  3.   cat-and-dog life - life full of quarrels
  4.   caught on the wrong foot - caught when one is not ready
  5.   clean break - quick and final
  6.   close-fisted - miserly
  7.   completely at sea – puzzled
  8.   count chickens before they are hatch – to Imagine a profitable outcome before investing.
  9.   crocodile tears -false tears
  10.   cross the rubicon – to reach a point
  11.   cut corners - take a short-cut
  12.   cut the ground from under someone’s feet - leave someone in a weak position
  13.   cut someone dead - treat someone as a complete stranger.
  14.   darken one's door - not to be welcome at someone’s house
  15.   die hard – old-fashioned, inflexible and unwilling to change
  16.   dirt cheap - extremely cheap
  17.   do away with - get rid of
  18.   down to earth – practical
  19.   draw a blank - find nothing
  20.   draw the line - fix the limit
  21.   Dutch courage -bravery induced by alcoholic liquors
  22.   easier said than done - easier to talk about than to do
  23.   eat one’s heart out - feel very unhappy over something
  24.   eat one’s words - take back something said earlier
  25.   ends of the earth - remote faraway places
  26.   face the music - take punishment.
  27.   fair and square - with justice and honesty
  28.   fall on deaf ears - to be ignored
  29.   fall on one’s feet - get out of a difficulty successfully
  30.   fall through - come to nothing
  31.   feel in one’s bones have – have a strong feeling about something.
  32.   feet of clay – a weakness or hidden flaw
  33.   fish in troubled waters - take advantage of a troubled state of affairs
  34.   fit as a fiddle - in very good health
  35.   fly off at a tangent - change suddenly to a different course of thought or action

 

List of idiomatic expressions and their meaning (G – H)

  1.   gain ground - make progress
  2.   get along with - be friendly and in harmony with
  3.   get away with - be successful in something which usually results in punishment or misfortune
  4.   get down to - deal seriously with
  5.   get hold of the wrong end of the stick - be mistaken about something
  6.   get into hot water - get into trouble
  7.   get it into one’s head that - understand
  8.   get on one nerves - irritate
  9.   get over - forget
  10.   give a piece of one’s mind - punish or scold
  11.   give the game away - reveal a secret plan
  12.   give up the ghost - die
  13.   glimmer of hope – a faint ray of hope
  14.   go at it hammer and tongs - fight or argue with energy and noise
  15.   go bananas - act crazily
  16.   go by the book – follow the rules
  17.   go off one’s head - become crazy
  18.   go off the deep end - express feelings without any control
  19.   golden opportunity – an excellent chance to do or get something
  20.   I hard up - short of money
  21.   hard and fast rules - strict rules
  22. have a go at -to try - have an axe to grind have some selfish objective in view
  23. have at one’s fingertips - be thoroughly familiar with have one’s handsfull very busy
  24. have one’s heart in one’s mouth - be frightened
  25. have the game in one hand - sure of winning
  26. head over heels - deeply, completely
  27. heart and soul - with all one’s effort
  28. high and dry - alone and helpless
  29. hit below the belt - act unfairly
  30. hit the nail on the head - guess correctly
  31. hold one’s tongue - keep silent

 

 

UNN PUTME Example

After the initial confusion, the Manager's suggestion brought _____ to the depressed investors.

A. a glitter of hope. B. a sparkle of hope. C. a raise of hope. D. a glimmer of hope

(a glimmer of hope).

 

Example

Ike is head over heels in love with Ngozi. This means that

A. Ike is friendly with Ngozi. B. Ike is trying to fall in love with Ngozi. C. Ngozi fell on Ike’s heel and both of them fell in love D. Ike is madly in love with Ngozi. E. none of the above.

(D. Totally, illogically in love with the world turned upside-down so-to-speak) 

 

Example

Ijeoma counted her chickens before they were hatched.

This means that Ijeoma

A. regarded each egg as a chicken B. hatched the eggs prematurely C. assumed that her expectations had already been realized D. protected her eggs from breaking E. insured the eggs.

(assumed that her expectations had already been realized)

 

Example

Old customs die hard. This implies that old customs

A. cause a lot of hardship and death B. must be stopped C. never die out

D. cause hardship for younger people E. tend to last for a long time.

(tend to last for a long time)

 

 

List of idiomatic expressions and their meaning (I –  L)

  1. in a nutshell - briefly
  2. in cold blood - purposely and without feeling
  3. in black and white - in writing
  4. in one ear and out the other - heard but without effect
  5. in the nick of time - just before it is too late
  6. in the same boat - in the same unfortunate circumstance I
  7. keep a straight face - hide one’s amusement by not smiling or laughing
  8. keep an eye on - to watch carefully, to look after
  9. keep one's head - keep calm
  10. keep one’s head above water - stay out of difficulty
  11. keep one’s nose to the grindstone - make one work hard without rest
  12. keep the ball rolling - keep things going
  13. keep your shirt on – to tell someone to calm down or be more patient
  14. let the cat out of the bag - tell what should be kept a secret
  15. let the sleeping dog lie – to avoid resolving a matter
  16. leave in the lurch – to abandon someone in a difficult situation
  17. lead a dog’s life – very unhappy and unpleasant life
  18. like a fish out of water - in a place not suited to one
  19. like nobody’s business - extraordinarily
  20. like water off a duck’s back - with no effect or reaction
  21. live from hand to mouth - live in hardship
  22. live in each other’s pockets – to be too close to someone, spend too much time with someone
  23. living in a fool's paradise – to be in a happy state for foolish, unfounded, or delusional reasons
  24. lock, stock and barrel - the whole of everything
  25. look down one’s nose at - treat haughtily
  26. look for a needle in a haystack - begin searching for something with only a slim chance of success
  27. lose face - be humiliated
  28. lose one's head - become confused or over-excited
  29. make a clean breast of - confess
  30. make do - to get along with what one has fun
  31. make ends meet - manage financially
  32. make no bones about it - be plain and frank
  33. make one’s blood run cold - fill with horror
  34. make one's mark - to succeed brilliantly
  35. make sense - have a meaning
  36. make the mouth water - cause to desire
  37. mind one’s P ’s and Q’s - be careful and polite about what one says or does
  38. mind your own business - do not interfere in the affairs of other people
  39. next of kin - the nearest of relations
  40. nip in the bud - stop something at the beginning stage
  41. not turn a hair - show no fear
  42. not up to the mark - not measuring up to a required standard
  43. on the dot - at the exact time or point
  44. once in a blue moon – rarely, once in a very long time
  45. out of hand - out of control
  46. out of the blue - unexpected
  47. out of date - old-fashioned

 

Example

The students were as Wised to face their studies and let the sleeping dog lie. This means that the students shout 

A. obey the authorities. B. organise them properly. C. leave matters as they are now. D. be as watchful as sleeping dogs.

(leave matters as they are now)

 

List of idiomatic expressions and their meaning (P – S)

  1. pay through the nose - pay an unreasonable price
  2. pick someone’s brain - get ideas from someone
  3. pitch a tent – support/have an erection
  4. play fast and loose - act carelessly
  5. plumb the depths – to reach the lowest point
  6. pooh-pooh an idea - express disbelief or contempt
  7. pull one’s leg - try to make someone believe an untruth as a joke
  8. pull strings - court the favour of important people in order to secure some benefit
  9. pull / wear a long face - look sad and glum
  10. put an end to - stop
  11. put one’s foot in it - spoil something
  12. put one’s shoulder to the wheel - to work hard in order to succeed
  13. put the cart before the horse - start at the wrong end
  14. rain cats and dogs - rain heavily
  15. red-letter day – a day of great importance
  16. rest on one’s laurels - retire from active life after gaining distinction in the field of sports or athletics
  17. road to Damascus – an important moment of insight that leads to a dramatic transformation of attitude or belief.
  18. rub shoulders with - meet and mix with (people)
  19. rub the wrong way - irritate
  20. runaway success - great, immediate success
  21. run into someone - meet unexpectedly
  22. run someone down - say unkind things about someone
  23. see eye to eye - agree completely
  24. sell like hot cakes - very readily or quickly
  25. send one packing - dismiss quickly
  26. send to Coventry - ignore as a punishment
  27. show a clean pair of heels - run away
  28. show one’s teeth - look angry
  29. Sit on the fence - avoid taking sides
  30. smell a rat - be suspicious/auspicious
  31. spick and span - neat and clean
  32. split hairs - argue over trifles "
  33. spread like wildfire - news passed round with astonishing speed
  34. steal the show - attract all the attention
  35. steer/take a middle course – adopt a policy which avoids extremes
  36. strike while the iron is hot - act without delay while the situation is favourable
  37. Stuck up - conceited, proud

 

PUME Example

The driver smelled a rat when the policemen asked him to stop.] It means that the driver was

A. reckless. B. auspicious. C. careful. D. offensive.

(auspicious)

 

List of idiomatic expressions and their meaning (T - W)

  1. tail between your legs – defeated and ashamed
  2. take French leave - absent without permission
  3. take leave of one’s senses - become mad
  4. take something with a grain/pinch of salt – to view something with skepticism or not to interpret something literally
  5. take the bull by the horns - tackle a problem boldly
  6. take the cake - be the best of the lot take to one’s heels run away
  7. talk one’s way out – to avoid unpleasant things by saying desirable things to people
  8. the lion’s share - the largest part
  9. the proof of the pudding is in the eating - people are judged by their actions
  10. thick in the head - stupid
  11. throw cold water on - discourage
  12. throw dust in the eyes - deceive
  13. throw weight about­ – to excessively exercise influence or authority
  14. to be on one's last legs - to be on the verge of min
  15. to be on tenterhooks - to be in a state of suspense and anxiety
  16. to bring up the rear - to be the last in line
  17. to kill the goose that laid the golden egg - to lose a valuable source of income through greed
  18. to make both ends meet – to survive
  19. to play second fiddle - to take a more junior position
  20. to pull the wool over someone’s eyes – to try to deceive someone
  21. to put one’s best foot forward - to do the best possible
  22. to ride roughshod over - to treat in a high-handed manner
  23. to scrape something together - to obtain with great effort
  24. to Stand out a mile - to be extremely obvious
  25. to stand someone in good stead - to be useful or helpful to someone in time of need
  26. to stand your ground – to continue in your beliefs
  27. to strain at a gnat and swallow a camel - to be overly particular in small things and lax in more important ones
  28. to take with a grain of salt - to accept with doubt
  29. to throw in the towel - to admit defeat
  30. touch and go - an uncertain or dangerous situation
  31. turn over a new leaf - conduct oneself better
  32. turn the other cheek - accept attack, refuse to take revenge
  33. turn the tables - reverse the result
  34. turn turtle - overturn
  35. turn up one’s nose - be scornful of
  36. under one’s very nose - directly in front of one
  37. walk away with - win easily
  38. wash one’s dirty linen in public - discuss unpleasant personal or family affairs in the presence of other people
  39. wear one’s heart on one’s sleeve - to behave so that one’s feelings are clear to all
  40. well begun is half-done - a good start makes it easy to finish something
  41. whistle in the dark - do something to overcome one’s fears
  42. widow's mite – a small contribution given by a person who has very little
  43. with a high hand - with arrogance
  44. worm something out of someone - get information by persistent questioning.

 

PUME Example

The economic situation is so bad that many wage earners are hardly able to make both ends meet. This means that

A. people's income exceed their expenditure. B. most people are extravagant with their income. C. people's earnings are not sufficient for their essential needs. D. most people engage in activities that bring them extra pay.

(people's earnings are not sufficient for their essential needs)

 

Jamb Example

The legislator has decided to play second fiddle after he had been walked out of the Assembly for violating basic procedure of the House. This means that the legislator has decided to

A. oppose every motion in the House B. support every motion in the House

C. condemn every motion D. support the lead given by others E. become active in the house.

(support the lead given by others)

 

 

PUME Example

1. It is usually hard to change the course of action when one crosses the Rubicon. The underlined expression, as used in this sentence, means to.

A. pass through a place called Rubicon. B. cross a river called Rubicon. C. cross a bridge called Rubicon

D. be irrevocably committed

(be irrevocably committed).

 

PUME Example

2. "It is irrational for one to count one's chickens before the eggs hatched."

A. The eggs are not to be broken. B. Not everything works out as outlined. C. One should not regard one's eggs as chickens. D. It is senseless to hatch one's eggs prematurely

(Not everything works out as outlined).

 

PUTME Example

3. The President stood his ground because the Committee members would not be persuaded to arrive at a compromise on the issue being debated.

A. yielded his position. B. shifted his position. C. maintained his position

D. defended his position. E. resisted his position

C. maintained his position (2015/2016, no 8)

 

JAMB Examples

1. The amount he donated was small. He said it was his widow's mite. This means that

A. he was a widow. B. he was misery. C. it was all he could honestly afford. D. he could have given more.

(it was all he could honestly afford)

 

2. Since I found out his hypocritical nature, I have been keeping him at arm's length. This mean: that I ___

A. avoid being similar with him. B. ignore his advice. C. report him to the authority. D). stop visiting him.

(avoid being similar with him).

 

3. Anyone who thinks that he can succeed in life without working hard is living in a fool's paradise. This means is that such a person

A. is having an illusion. B. thinks other people are fools. C. thinks hat working is merely a joke. D. is on the verge of insanity.

(is having an illusion)

 

4. As the drama unfolded, Olatinuke was advised to keep her shirt on (a) she was advised to stay calm (b) she was advised to commit herself (c) she was advised to join the club (d) she was advised to wear her shirt

(she was advised to stay calm)

 

5. The team's poor performance at the tournament plumbed the depths of horror.

(a) the team's performance was rewarded (b) the team's performance took them to the next round (c) the team's performance was enjoyed by all (d) the team's performance was full of disappointment

(the team's performance was full of disappointment)

 

6. The lecture is Uye’s road to Damascus.

A. The lecture is an opportunity to travel to Damascus. B. The lecture is an experience that changes the way she thinks. C. The lecture talks exclusively about Damascus. D. The lecture is an experience that cannot be changed.

(The lecture is an experience that changes the way she thinks)

 

7. Bello said he would pitch his tent with the club.

A. He would support the club. B. He would build a pitch in the club. C. He would build a tent on the pitch. D. He would distance himself from the club.

(He would support the club)

 

8. Tolu and Chinedu live in each other’s pockets.
A. They are long-term business partners. B. They steal from each other. C. They blackmail each other. D. They are very close to each other.
(They are very close to each other)
 

9. The vice chancellor is riding the crest of the last quarter of his administration.

(a) The vice chancellor enjoys the acknowledgement of the success of his administration

(b) The vice chancellor does not enjoy the people’s criticism of his administration

(c) The vice chancellor hopes to overcome soon, the poor comments on his administration

(d) The vice chancellor does not talk of his successes on office

(The vice chancellor enjoys the acknowledgement of the success of his administration)

 

10. The landlord is fond of throwing his weight about
(a) The landlord likes healthy exercise. (b) The landlord is overweight, (c) The landlord gives orders to people. (d) The landlord is respected by his tenants
(The landlord gives orders to people)
 


11. He could not speak out because he had a foot of clay.
(a) His feet was muddy. (b) He was weak and cowardly. (c) He was clumsy and lazy. (d) He was shy and timid
(He was shy and timid)

 

12. The player wasted a golden opportunity during the penalty shoot-out.

(a) The player first the bar. (b) The player did not score the shot. (c) The player scored the shot that made them win the gold cup. (d) Instead of a silver cup, they received the golden one

(The player did not score the shot)

 

13. She stopped her education as her uncle left her in the lurch.

(a) Her uncle deceived her. (b) Her uncle disinherited her. (c) Her uncle refused to help her

(d) Her uncle disrespected her

(Her uncle refused to help her)

 

14. It was good to steer a middle course in whatever one does.
A. It is always good to get midway in anything one does
B. It is always good to act with moderation
C. It is always good to move away from the forefront
D. It is always good to work very hard.
(It is always good to act with moderation)

 

15. The footballers moved with their tails between their legs.

A. they moved happily because they won the match

B. they were unhappy because they had been despised by their opponents

C. they were ashamed because they had been defeated

D. they moved with their tails between their legs.

(they were ashamed because they had been defeated)

 

16. The headmaster managed to talk his way out of having to give a speech

A. he delivered a speech despite the difficulty

B. he managed to give a speech out of a difficult situation

C. he managed to get himself out of a difficult situation

D. he managed to talk on his way.

(he managed to get himself out of a difficult situation)

 

17. As regards the matter, we have crossed the rubicon

A. we are completely at a loss B. we are irrevocably committed

C. we are already qualified D. we are perfectly committed

(we are irrevocably committed)

 

18. The story has to be taken with a grain of salt. This means that

A. you need some salt to listen to the story. B. there is no salt in the story. C. the story is questionable D. the story is true E. you have too much salt in the story.

(the story is questionable)

 

19. It is usually hard to change the course of action when one crosses the Rubicon. The underlined expression, as used in this sentence, means to

A. pass through a place called Rubicon B. cross a river called Rubicon C. cross a bridge called Rubicon

D. pass a special test E. be irrevocably committed.

(be irrevocably committed)

 

20. The saleman tried to pull the wool over my eyes. This implies that the salesman tried to

A. force me to buy his goods B. offer me cotton wool C. make me buy his wool

D. dupe me E. cover my eyes with wool.

(dupe me)

 

21. The convict said he was tire of leading a dog’s life. To lead a dog’s life means to live

A. carelessly B. in disgrace C. in solitude D. in misery E. in poverty.

(in misery)
